headline: How Are Ties Broken in Tennis? That Depends
abstract: There are four Grand Slam tournaments, and this year they each will have a different way to solve a tie.
first_paragraph: Difficult as it might be to remember at this time-is-money stage in tennis, the sport once had no tiebreakers.
keywords: ['Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'French Open (Tennis)', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Masters Golf Tournament']

headline: The Masters on Halloween? Golf Weighs Tradition Against the Calendar
abstract: The five different governing bodies of golf’s most prestigious tournaments are considering unconventional concessions in order to salvage the season.
first_paragraph: If golf’s biggest events are to be salvaged this year, the game’s leaders must find an uncommon wellspring of creativity and flexibility. The first two men’s Grand Slam events of the year, the Masters and the P.G.A. Championship, have already been postponed indefinitely, and the schedules for the two others, the United States and British Opens, are teetering as the coronavirus increasingly alters lives around the globe.
keywords: ['Golf', 'PGA Championship', 'United States Open (Golf)', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'British Open (Golf)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: Where the Major Sports Stand Amid the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: A snapshot look at how the global sports calendar has shifted because of the virus.
first_paragraph: Nearly every sporting event, major and minor, has been canceled, moved or postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic. The question now, to which no one really knows the answer, is when games will come back.
keywords: ['UEFA Champions League (Soccer)', 'United States Open (Golf)', "Giro d'Italia (Bicycle Race)", 'PGA Championship', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'British Open (Golf)', 'London Marathon', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Preakness Stakes', 'French Open (Tennis)', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Indianapolis 500 (Auto Race)']

headline: What We Miss Without the Masters
abstract: The collective gathering to view the tournament’s poignant trademark finale is as much of an event as the golf itself.
first_paragraph: The day after his stirring, historic victory at last year’s Masters tournament, Tiger Woods grabbed his cellphone to check the feedback about his monumental achievement.

headline: With Masters Postponed, Not Canceled, Golfers Hope for a Do-Over
abstract: Golf’s first major tournament of the season was postponed indefinitely on Friday because of the spread of coronavirus.
first_paragraph: The 2020 Masters Tournament, golf’s first major championship and a signature, springtime event in American sports, was postponed Friday morning by its host, the Augusta National Golf Club, because of the coronavirus pandemic that has led to sweeping changes across the world.

headline: A Tolerable Redemption for Tiger Woods
abstract: His journey back has been morally and medically arduous. But here he is, basking in adulation, smiling with President Trump, defying his sport’s and society’s expectations.
first_paragraph: Last month, the president awarded Tiger Woods the Presidential Medal of Freedom. The ceremony took place in the White House Rose Garden, a couple of weeks after Woods’s desperately prayed-for win at the Masters golf tournament.
keywords: ['Golf', 'United States Open (Golf)', 'Presidential Medal of Freedom', 'Masters Golf Tournament']

headline: Bryson DeChambeau’s Golf Revolution Turns Toward the Masters
abstract: DeChambeau aims to conquer genteel Augusta National with brute force. Given his play since bulking up over the past year, lots of golfers — and bettors — think he can.
first_paragraph: Asked about his childhood as he stood on the practice range at a golf tournament in Connecticut this summer, Bryson DeChambeau said his overriding memory was a conviction that a nonconformist would eventually get more done.
keywords: ['Golf', 'United States Open (Golf)', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']

headline: Count Tiger Woods Out? Not at Augusta National
abstract: Woods’s 2019 Masters win was one of the most dramatic revivals in sports. Despite his back pain and the tournament’s odd November start, most expect him to contend for a record-tying sixth victory.
first_paragraph: The most mesmerizing moment of Tiger Woods’s seismic 2019 Masters victory featured the intimidating stillness of a silent stare. Standing defiantly on the 12th green with arms folded across his chest during the final round, Woods glared pitilessly at his closest rivals.

headline: At Augusta National, Not Talking About Race Is Tradition
abstract: A plan to honor Lee Elder, the first Black golfer to compete in the Masters, highlights the glacial pace of change at the club that hosts golf’s marquee event.
first_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has silenced the Masters Tournament’s resonant roars. It has erased the par-3 contest, drained the color from the wintering azaleas and brought brisk north winds into play for the first time. This week’s tournament, rescheduled from the first major of the year to the last and stripped down to better safeguard the participants from the virus, is happening in one kind of bubble.

headline: Detonating the Masters, One Power Drive at a Time
abstract: Bryson DeChambeau mapped out his Masters plan on Tuesday, which included bombing his tee shots over 100-foot tall pine trees and maybe breaking out the longest driver in golf.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bryson DeChambeau was specific on Tuesday about his long-driving plans to brazenly overrun the Augusta National Golf Club, home to the Masters tournament since 1934. For sports fans who do not follow golf, here are some points of reference:

headline: What’s Different About a November Masters?
abstract: A lot. No sporting event does springtime iconography like the Masters. But many of its traditions have been altered as men's golf’s first major moved to fall.
first_paragraph: The Masters does set-your-watch-to-it formality better than any sporting event. From the prominent green jacket ceremony to the mundane paint on sewer covers, every detail of the tournament is coordinated and beholden to a familiar presentation. This is how the youngest of the men’s golf major championships achieved such rapid brand strength and popularity.

headline: The 2020 Masters: DeChambeau’s Challengers Aren’t Exactly Long Shots
abstract: The world No. 5 golfer Rory McIlroy and the second-ranked Jon Rahm could stand in the way of the long-driving Bryson DeChambeau’s quest for a green jacket.
first_paragraph: The Masters, as its name might convey, has the smallest field in men’s major championship golf by a considerable margin. The United States Open, British Open, and P.G.A. Championship all have 156-player fields, while Augusta National almost never extends invitations to more than 100 players — and prefers to stay comfortably below that mark.

headline: Augusta’s Green Jackets: For Winners, Members (and Buyers) Only
abstract: The club’s green jackets — awarded to its members and Masters winners — are not supposed to leave its grounds. A rare few have, becoming an expensive holy grail for memorabilia collectors.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Christopher O’Brien is not a member of Augusta National Golf Club, much less a Masters champion. He once played the course “well enough to enjoy it, not well enough to brag about it.”
keywords: ['Golf', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs']

headline: Tiger Woods Starts Strong at the Masters as Paul Casey Leads an Incomplete Round
abstract: Casey shot seven under par on Thursday, and Woods was four under, after rain delayed the start of tournament and left many golfers with unfinished rounds.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At ease as he played his 87th round at the Masters, Tiger Woods stalked the Augusta National Golf Club on Thursday with the aplomb of someone sauntering through his living room in search of his favorite recliner, foot stool and coaster, for the cool drink in his hand. Shot by shot, the path was so familiar he could have negotiated it in the dark.

headline: What to Expect on Day 2 of the 2020 Masters
abstract: Thursday’s rain delay means many players will have to scramble to finish the second round of the tournament, which Paul Casey leads at seven under par.
first_paragraph: Thursday’s morning rainstorm at Augusta National sufficiently muddled plans at the 2020 Masters. But after a nearly three-hour delay that thwarted Bryson DeChambeau’s strategy for domination — he rebounded from a double-bogey on the par-5 13th hole to shoot a two-under-par 70 — play resumed with 27 of the 48 players who had finished their rounds breaking par for the day. Among them was the reigning champion, Tiger Woods, who logged a four-under 68 on Day 1 to finish three strokes behind the leader, the Englishman Paul Casey.

headline: For Aging Masters Champions, Pandemic Cannot Mute Augusta’s Call
abstract: Despite the coronavirus crisis, many of the older men who won the Masters reunited at the tournament that helped make them famous. Some are even playing.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The men met for dinner at Augusta National Golf Club on Tuesday night. They donned their green jackets, asked after grandchildren, cracked wise, drank wine and thought back to the long-ago shots that were their meal tickets now.

headline: Bryson DeChambeau’s Ball Search Pushes Him Out of Masters Hunt
abstract: After predictions that he would dominate Augusta National, DeChambeau had a meltdown on the third hole Friday that put him below the projected cut line with six holes of his second round left to finish on Saturday morning.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was almost a given that Bryson DeChambeau would do something memorable at this year’s Masters tournament. It did not figure to be a booming tee shot so high in the Georgia sky that it landed clear out of sight.

headline: A Lack of Fans at the Masters Strains Those Who Would Sell the Experience
abstract: Passes to the Masters are some of the most expensive tickets in sports. But with fans barred from Augusta National Golf Club and other venues this year, many resellers are under pressure.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For about two decades, James DiZoglio has run a bazaar to sell some of the most cherished tickets in sports. His scalping locale has always been the same: near the TBonz Steakhouse and the Augusta Best Inn down the street from the site of the Masters.

headline: Rory McIlroy Aims for Balance, and a Green Jacket
abstract: McIlroy, still seeking a Masters win for a career Grand Slam, struggled in the first round at Augusta National but rebounded in the second.
first_paragraph: Rory McIlroy watched the flight of his ball in dismay on Friday morning. “That’s so bad,” he said. “Oh my God.”

headline: Masters Mentorship Puts Tournament Rookies on Top
abstract: On Saturday, 14 first-timers made the rain-delayed cut, a Masters record. Many of them benefited from pretournament sessions with seasoned Masters veterans.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — By the time he reached Augusta National Golf Club’s 17th tee during Monday’s practice round, Cameron Champ had talked with his stand-in coach and tour guide about his upcoming wedding and how to navigate the course’s greens.

headline: Dustin Johnson Widens Masters Lead and Eyes Scoring Record
abstract: The No. 1-ranked golfer played in one lead-up event before the Masters after a positive coronavirus test felled him in October. Despite the rust, he leads the field by four strokes after three rounds.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Perhaps it is fitting that the player leading the biggest golf tournament of 2020 prepared for the event last month by self-isolating in a hotel room for 11 days after a positive coronavirus test result.

headline: The 2020 Masters: Dustin Johnson Sets Scoring Record
abstract: Dustin Johnson won the Masters at 20 under, five strokes ahead of Australia’s Cameron Smith and Sungjae Im of South Korea.
first_paragraph: Dustin Johnson won the 2020 Masters and set a scoring record at 20 under par, two strokes better than the former record, held jointly by Tiger Woods and Jordan Spieth. Johnson, who grew up an hour away, in South Carolina, became the first world No. 1 to win the event since Woods in 2001.

headline: Dustin Johnson Wins 2020 Masters in Record Fashion
abstract: Johnson, the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, won with a score of 20 under par, the first player to reach that total at Augusta National.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For 10 years, Dustin Johnson’s chase for career-defining, major championship titles was tinged with ruthless angst, misfortune and calamitous setbacks.

headline: Tiger Woods Faced Disaster at the Masters. He Stuck Through It Anyway.
abstract: After a horrific appearance at No. 12, the five-time Masters winner did not fade — even with no hope of another green jacket and almost no one around to watch.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods had just birdied three holes on Sunday at the Masters when he stood at the tee box at No. 18. A few of the men sitting around the 17th green did not bother to watch.

headline: Will Augusta National’s New Event for Women Upstage L.P.G.A. Stars?
abstract: Augusta National officials have trumpeted their amateur invitational as a grand stage for women’s golf, even though it conflicts with the first major of the year.
first_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Albane Valenzuela could have been teeing it up Wednesday in the inaugural Augusta National Women’s Amateur, where the contestants who survive the cut will play the final 18 holes on the fabled course where men will compete at the Masters next week.

headline: The Snake Lady and the Masters: Augusta Imagines Life Post-Strip Clubs
abstract: It is hard to imagine Augusta without Whitey Lester, a downtown fixture for decades and the city’s last strip-club impresario.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — “Folks,” the radio host wrote on his Facebook page, “reports of Whitey Lester’s death were apparently incorrect.”

headline: Tiger Woods Hunts for Another Masters, a Decade After Crash
abstract: Tiger Woods’s life came apart 10 years ago. Then came surgeries on his back, battles with painkillers. Another green jacket would be nice.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The 10th anniversary of the Thanksgiving night car crash that changed the course of golf history is months away. But as a smiling Tiger Woods exited the Augusta National Golf Club clubhouse on Tuesday to cheers and applause, it was not too soon to consider his renaissance since the fall from grace that began when his then wife chased her philandering husband from their home and he drove his S.U.V. into a neighbor’s tree.

headline: Sergio García’s Hunt for the Perfect Caddie
abstract: He considered his wife and a former tennis star before settling on his brother. “He’s excited about caddying here, but it is not the holidays.”
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The first time that Sergio García’s older brother, Victor, caddied for him at the Masters, García handed him his putter on the ninth hole of the Wednesday par-3 contest and watched him drain a 25-foot birdie attempt. More than a decade later, Victor is again inside the ropes at Augusta National with his brother, but this time he will be shepherding García through the 72-hole tournament, which began Thursday.

headline: Brooks Koepka and Bryson DeChambeau Share the Masters Lead
abstract: Tiger Woods led for part of the opening round. He shot a two-under-par 70, the same first-round score he had when he won in 1997, 2001 and 2002.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The methodical, ever calculating Bryson DeChambeau, who last week put himself through a 14-hour practice session to decipher the effect of what he called the “spin loft curve” of his wedges, was asked late Thursday to assess the final nine holes of his first round at the 2019 Masters.

headline: Tony Finau, on Another Masters Adventure, Carries Memories of an Idol
abstract: Finau kept a ball signed by Billy Casper, the 1970 champion, in his bag during the opening round. Casper had offered encouragement to Finau when he was taking up golf.
first_paragraph: Tony Finau put a lucky 13th ball in his bag for his opening round of one-under-par 71 on Thursday at the Masters.

headline: A Masters Plastic Cup Is Almost as Treasured as a Green Jacket
abstract: People do strange things at Augusta National, including sifting through garbage cans in search of soft drink cups adorned with a certain logo.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The most coveted souvenir at the Masters is found in the garbage.

headline: A Pack of Champs Lead the Masters, and Tiger Woods Refuses to Be Tripped Up
abstract: Five major winners, including Francesco Molinari and Brooks Koepka, are tied at seven under par after the second round. Woods, despite a mishap on the course, is a stroke behind.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As Tiger Woods was making his stirring late charge up a bunched Masters leaderboard Friday, he was chasing a formidable cast of rivals that included six major golf championship winners.

headline: At the Masters, Jason Day Again Finds Pain and Perseverance
abstract: The Australian has been ridiculed for always being hobbled by some pain or ailment. This time, his back issues helped him sharpen his focus on the way to a share of the lead.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters is the major that Jason Day has dreamed of winning since he turned to golf as a teenager to escape an almost certain future working in a meatpacking plant in his native Australia. Day had to be plenty tough to overcome his impoverished beginnings, so it is strange that he has become known on the PGA Tour for his fragility.

headline: Eye-Opening Augusta
abstract: Once a year, Augusta National Golf Club opens its exclusive gates to the world for the Masters. The world is treated to a jewel of history and nature.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Augusta National Golf Club holds a unique place in the American psyche.

headline: Tiger Woods, in Range of Masters Win, Displays His Dominance for New Generation
abstract: Woods is tied for second going into the final round at Augusta National. A win would be something no one thought possible by him as recently as two years ago.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Twenty-two years after Tiger Woods raised the curtain on golf’s version of the Broadway sensation “Cats,” he has set the stage for a spellbinding encore.

headline: How Do You Know Tiger Woods Is Coming? Listen for the Roar
abstract: Ropes and security kept the crowds at the Masters in place, but nothing could contain the sound of their cheers when Woods was around. Imagine if he wins.
first_paragraph: The cheering was already raucous as Tiger Woods walked up the 18th fairway on Saturday, but when he smiled and tipped his cap, the volume doubled. The clamor diminished ever so slightly, and then Woods raised his putter in salute, and the roar reached new heights. A few strides later, Woods was on the green, and he offered a wave of his right hand and another grin. This time, the crowd erupted with its most thunderous ovation.

headline: Tiger Woods, in a Stirring Return to the Top, Captures the Masters at 43
abstract: After four back operations and nearly a decade of struggles on and off the golf course, Woods is back at the pinnacle.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods completed a comeback from personal and professional adversity on Sunday, capturing his fifth Masters title and his 15th major tournament with a victory that snapped a decade-long championship drought and instantly returned him to the top of the sports world.

headline: Tiger Woods Showed He Was Back Not With a Shot, but With a Stare
abstract: As he stood on the 12th green, glaring at Francesco Molinari and Tony Finau, Woods found the killer instinct he — and golf as a whole — had been missing.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — If Tiger Woods’s victory at the 2019 Masters is among the greatest comebacks in sports history — and it is at least a leading candidate — its origin will forever be traced to what happened on the 12th hole on Sunday when the old Tiger Woods suddenly reappeared at a major championship for the first time in 11 years.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Masters Win Joins the Ranks of Great Sports Comebacks
abstract: When athletes begin to fade, it’s usually all over. But a select few, including Michael Jordan and Monica Seles, have returned in triumph.
first_paragraph: Tiger Woods hadn’t won a major in 11 years. He had struggled through injury and personal crises. He was dismissed as finished, his years of dominance fading into memory.
keywords: ['Sports Injuries', 'Tennis', 'Football', 'Baseball', 'Boxing', 'Golf', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Horse Racing', 'Masters Golf Tournament']

headline: Tiger Woods Shook Up Golf at the Masters. It Might Be Just the Beginning.
abstract: A favorable schedule could put Woods in position for a serious run at winning all four majors this year, a feat never accomplished in the modern era.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Jack Nicklaus was fishing in the Bahamas on Sunday as Tiger Woods resumed circling him in the quest for Nicklaus’s record of 18 major golf championships. But in his news conference after winning the Masters for his 15th major title, Woods didn’t sound exactly bloodthirsty.

headline: Trump Says He Will Give Tiger Woods the Presidential Medal of Freedom
abstract: The president has lavished praise on Woods, a golf and business partner, for winning the Masters on Sunday in a dramatic comeback.
first_paragraph: A day after Tiger Woods won his fifth Masters title and 15th major tournament in a rousing resurrection of his career, President Trump said Monday he would give him an honor almost as exclusive as a green jacket from Augusta National Golf Club: the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

headline: Golf Looks to a Tiger Boom 2.0
abstract: Interest boomed and prize money skyrocketed after Tiger Woods burst onto the scene. In his absence it stagnated. Now comes another chance.
first_paragraph: Through Tiger Woods’s 11 years in the wilderness between major tournament wins, professional golf searched for a successor.

headline: December Date for U.S. Women’s Open Brings New Challenges
abstract: Golf’s final major tournament is set to play in Houston with coronavirus-related challenges, an unprecedented two-course format, and one of women’s golf’s largest purses.
first_paragraph: HOUSTON — The PGA Tour does not have a 72-hole stroke play event this week, and several weekend college football games, including the marquee matchup between Michigan and Ohio State, have been canceled or postponed because of the coronavirus, leaving the best female golfers in the world well positioned to fill the TV viewing void.

headline: Masters Preview? Rory McIlroy Wins at Bay Hill, and Tiger Woods Makes a Run
abstract: McIlroy earned his first PGA Tour victory since 2016, and Woods, who stayed in the hunt and tied for fifth, advanced his comeback from spinal surgery.
first_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Australian Adam Scott was asked last week if Tiger Woods could win the Masters.

headline: Tiger Woods Is Back. Will Sponsors Buy In?
abstract: Despite his troubles and controversies, golf fans seem willing — even eager — to embrace Mr. Woods’s comeback. Will corporate America feel the same?
first_paragraph: In the past few weeks, Tiger Woods has made a seemingly improbable comeback on the golf course. But can his image rebound the same way off it?

headline: Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson Warm Up Together, and to Each Other
abstract: Until Tuesday at Augusta National, Woods and Mickelson, golf’s great rivals for more than two decades, had never played a practice round before a major together.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods was on the driving range Tuesday at the Masters after playing nine holes in a foursome that included Phil Mickelson when Rory McIlroy sidled up and made him laugh. McIlroy said he had told Woods, “I never thought I’d see the day: Tiger and Phil playing a practice round at Augusta.”

headline: Matt Parziale Is an Amateur at the Masters, but a Pro Fighting Fires
abstract: Parziale’s often exhausting and sometimes dangerous grind paid off in October when he won the U.S. Mid-Amateur Championship, earning him a spot at the Masters.
first_paragraph: No offense to professional golfers, but Matt Parziale has a real job.

headline: Masters 2018: Players to Watch
abstract: Some old faces and some new ones, as players prepare for the first major of the season on the PGA Tour.
first_paragraph: Though the Masters rarely lacks for intrigue, the weekly parade of top-class winners this spring has brought stars into alignment like few other years. And that’s before you consider the return of a certain once-dominant big cat on the prowl again.

headline: At the Masters’ 12th Hole, Shots Are Left Twisting in the Wind
abstract: Golden Bell, as No. 12 at Augusta National Golf Club is also known, has caused more problems for competitors than almost any other hole on the course.
first_paragraph: No matter how many majors Jordan Spieth wins during his career, the 12th hole at Augusta National Golf Club will forever be the scene of heartbreak.

headline: Tiger Woods Bulked Up and Broke Down. Now He’s a ‘Walking Miracle’
abstract: Younger players who watched Woods push the limits, and endure years of pain, marvel at his latest comeback and aim for a balance between golf and life.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Bryson DeChambeau, a rising star on the PGA Tour, never imagined he would withdraw from a tournament just to avoid pain.

headline: How Jordan Spieth Took Control at the Masters
abstract: Five straight birdies put Spieth in the lead. Tiger Woods, healthy again and playing well, finished an up-and-down round at 1-over par. Here’s what happened.
first_paragraph: [Round 2: Follow our live Masters coverage.]

headline: Tiger Woods Is More Dogged Than Dazzling in His Return to the Masters
abstract: Woods, appearing in his first major tournament since 2015, shot a one-over-par 73 that required him to repeatedly dig out of trouble.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters patrons who flocked to watch Tiger Woods’s first round of a major tournament in 963 days did not see the dominant Woods, the surgeon who once carved up par 5s as if they were Easter hams.

headline: Tony Finau Steals Masters Spotlight After Dislocating Ankle
abstract: Finau had nearly withdrawn from the tournament after his injury on Wednesday, but he played and was tied for second after a wild first round on Thursday.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Maybe the tone of the opening day of the 2018 Masters tournament was set when the defending champion, Sergio García, hit five balls into the pond in front of the 15th hole for an eventual eight-over-par 13. It matched the highest score ever recorded on any hole at the Masters, which began in 1934.

headline: How Patrick Reed Dominated the Masters on Day 2
abstract: Reed leads the field after the second round of the Masters. Tiger Woods played well enough to make the cut, but he’s 13 strokes off the lead.
first_paragraph: Patrick Reed, who played college golf at Augusta State University, looked in command on a familiar course that caused problems for several other contenders, including Jordan Spieth, who lost his two-stroke advantage after Thursday’s round with a double bogey right on the first hole. Reed, on the other hand, finished with nine birdies to shoot 66, the low round of the day, for a two-shot lead over the Australian Marc Leishman (-7) heading into the weekend.

headline: Day 2 at the Masters Starts With Mayhem and Ends With Patrick Reed in the Lead
abstract: Reed shot a six-under-par 66 and held a two-stroke lead over Marc Leishman. Lurking behind them were eight major winners, while Tiger Woods barely made the cut.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The second round of the Masters opened with tumult and sloppy play.

headline: At the Masters, Low-Tech Data Still Rules
abstract: At Augusta National, caddies and players receive yardage books that provide rudimentary information compared with what is often available at other tournaments. So they have to fill in the blanks.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The caddie William Lanier was standing behind Augusta National’s 13th hole on Monday, scribbling in a notebook roughly the size of a king-size candy bar, when he overheard a patron ask her husband, “What’s inside those books?”

headline: Patrick Reed Leads the Masters, With Rory McIlroy’s Grand Slam Hopes Lurking
abstract: McIlroy posted a seven-under-par 65 on Saturday and ended the third round three strokes behind Reed, who has yet to win a major.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — One round now separates Rory McIlroy from one of golf’s most elite constituencies. If on Sunday he can reel in Patrick Reed, the Masters’ 54-hole leader, McIlroy will become the sixth man — and the first since Tiger Woods in 2000 — to complete a career grand slam.

headline: Rickie Fowler, Within Reach of a Masters Title, Tries to Keep the Past at Bay
abstract: Less flamboyant, but no less determined, Fowler will seek his first victory in a major tournament on Sunday. He has been close before.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Rickie Fowler is 29 years old now. The hair is shorter; the golf hat has shrunk; the wardrobe has lost its flamboyance.

headline: Patrick Reed Wins the Masters in a Breakthrough Performance
abstract: Reed, 27, had never won a major before, and he had never finished in the top 20 at the Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Sunday at the Masters began with Patrick Reed and Rory McIlroy in a final-round pairing that resurrected memories of the 2016 Ryder Cup at Hazeltine National Golf Club, where Reed got the best of McIlroy in a riveting singles match.

headline: Jordan Spieth Misses a Victory, but Gains Another Masters Memory
abstract: Spieth’s furious charge came up short on Sunday, but he has established himself as a perennial story line at Augusta National.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — When Jordan Spieth’s birdie putt on the 16th green dropped into the hole just after 5:40 p.m. on another stirring Masters Sunday, Spieth had made up the nine strokes that formed the gap between him and Patrick Reed at the beginning of the day.

headline: Masters Tournament Will Allow Limited Number of Fans to Attend
abstract: After hosting the 2020 event without spectators in November, six months delayed from its usual spring date, Augusta National Golf Club announced it would restore some tradition.
first_paragraph: This year’s Masters tournament in April will be attended by a limited number of spectators, the Augusta National Golf Club announced Tuesday. The club, which prohibited fans from the event two months ago, did not specify how many fans would be allowed in 2021, adding that spectators would be permitted if, “it can be done safely.”

headline: Four Fresh Major Champions, but Still No Golf Savior
abstract: Four first-time major champions last combined to capture golf’s top titles in 2011, perhaps the start of the post-Tiger Woods era. But all the fresh faces have failed to command the sport.
first_paragraph: Spotted in the gallery at the P.G.A. Championship this weekend was a spectator wearing a bright red T-shirt — as boldly red as Donald J. Trump’s favorite baseball cap. Across the chest of the T-shirt were four words, written in white capital letters: “Make Tiger Great Again.”
keywords: ['Golf', 'PGA Championship', 'United States Open (Golf)', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'British Open (Golf)']

headline: ‘A Steel-Nerved Master’: How We Introduced Arnold Palmer in 1958
abstract: After winning The Masters, Palmer was featured in a “Man in the News” column in The New York Times.
first_paragraph: Arnold Palmer won the first of his seven major championships at the Masters in 1958. Here is an excerpt from Man in the News column in The New York Times on April 7, 1958.

headline: Tiger Woods Out of Surgery and ‘Recovering’ After Serious Car Crash
abstract: The greatest golfer of his generation sustained leg injuries in the accident that, along with a recent back surgery, could raise questions about the future of his career.
first_paragraph: For Tiger Woods, it was a resounding comeback. After a back injury that had seemed destined to end his career, he won the Masters Tournament in 2019, a thrilling return to form that captivated the nation.

headline: What to Know About Tiger Woods’s Car Crash and Condition
abstract: Woods is recovering from “serious” leg injuries, which are not believed to be life-threatening. The authorities are investigating the crash solely as an accident, not as a criminal case.
first_paragraph: Tiger Woods was rushed to a hospital with serious leg injuries on Tuesday morning in Los Angeles County after he was involved in a single-car crash in a hilly area known for car crashes. After emergency surgery on Tuesday, Woods underwent additional procedures on Friday and was said to be “recovering and in good spirits,” according to a statement.

headline: Golf Without Tiger Woods? His Fellow Players Can Barely Imagine
abstract: Woods, 45, has been sidelined before as he recovered from various ailments. But this time, after a car crash that left him with serious leg injuries, feels different.
first_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — As a golf prodigy growing up in Northern Ireland, Rory McIlroy not only yearned to compete against his idol Tiger Woods but also hoped to become his good friend. Both dreams came true.
keywords: ['Golf', 'PGA Championship', 'Masters Golf Tournament', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']

headline: Tiger Woods and Another Terrible Turn of Fate
abstract: It is easy to cling to memories of Tiger Woods at his peaks, but his vulnerability tells as much, if not more, about his powerful hold on sport and culture.
first_paragraph: The sight of his demolished S.U.V., sitting forlornly on a grassy Southern California hillside, belied the image of Tiger Woods as an invincible force marching across the golf course to certain, thrilling triumph.

headline: For a Golf Tinkerer, a Strategy Just Crazy Enough to Work
abstract: Bryson DeChambeau, a 22-year-old amateur, will play the Masters with equipment that some observers find baffling: His irons and wedges are the same length and weight.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — How to improve one’s game? It is the eternal question for golfers, as predictable as their next shank. When planted in Bryson DeChambeau’s fertile mind, the query flourished like the grape vines climbing vines from the rich soil of the San Joaquin Valley in California, where he grew into one of the world’s top amateurs.

headline: A Spot at Augusta, Finally, and a Comrade in Trump
abstract: After shooting a sizzling round in March with Donald J. Trump, who helped finance his career, Jim Herman earned his first PGA Tour win and a berth in his first Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Donald J. Trump jumped at the opportunity to make Jim Herman’s game great. Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, peeled away from the campaign trail last month to play a round of golf with Herman, whose PGA Tour career he has helped finance.

headline: Jason Day’s Long Rise to No. 1 Began With a Mother’s Save
abstract: Day’s mother, Dening, sent him to a boarding school as a teenager to save him from the streets, after life with an abusive, controlling father.
first_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — Jason Day’s rise to No. 1 in the world began with a rusted golf club retrieved from a Queensland junkyard.
keywords: ['Golf', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Masters Golf Tournament']

headline: Jordan Spieth, Humbly, Gets Ready to Defend Masters Crown
abstract: Spieth, who won the first two majors of 2015 and ended the year by buying a sprawling estate, is still tiptoeing around Augusta.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The question posed Tuesday to the reigning Masters champion was about winning four majors in the same year. Is a men’s calendar Grand Slam achievable? With his response, Jordan Spieth humorously addressed how his life changed in 2015 when he became only the second golfer in the last 43 years to win the first two legs.

headline: For Masters, Waiting Is the Hardest Part
abstract: The first shot of this year’s Masters will be struck 235 days after the last putt of the P.G.A. Championship, rattling some players’ nerves.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Adam Scott had to go two extra holes of sudden death with Ángel Cabrera to become the first Australian to win the Masters. Scott said he was less nervous before the start of that 2013 playoff than he will be Thursday when he stands at the No. 1 tee box for the first drive of his 15th Masters.

headline: Augusta Presents a Steep Challenge (So Wear the Right Shoes)
abstract: Traction turns out to be vital even on a dry day watching the Masters, with Augusta National’s lush terrain more sweeping than meets a spectator’s eye.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Note to self and all other Masters rookies: Do not wear loafers to Augusta National.

headline: Tiger Woods Is Missing, but So Is Dominance in Golf
abstract: As Woods misses the Masters for only the second time in 22 years, today’s top golfers can only marvel at how long he was able to rule the sport.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Four of the six amateurs in the Masters field this week were born after Tiger Woods made his Augusta National debut in 1995. They grew up in a world in which Woods’s contending in a major was a given, like spring following winter.

headline: The Achilles’ Heel of Too Many Golfers: A Bad Back
abstract: Phil Mickelson says proper technique can avoid injuries; Bryson DeChambeau, an amateur, believes in same-length irons.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In his 24th Masters, Phil Mickelson is an evangelist spreading the gospel according to Ernest Jones, whose 1937 book, “Swing the Clubhead Method,” is Mickelson’s sacred text. He teed off Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club with a fourth green jacket in his sights and a message to spread about longevity in the sport.

headline: 9 Strokes, Then What? For Ernie Els, On to 2nd Hole
abstract: Els’s 9 was the highest score on the first hole in the 80-year history of the Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The first hole at Augusta National, a par 4 measuring 445 yards, requires players to hit from an elevated tee to a fairway that breaks right to left, then hit their second shots to an elevated green. It calls to mind a roller coaster, and it made a few stomachs drop during the opening round of the Masters.

headline: Ah, Those Augusta Memories (of 2015): Jordan Spieth Races to Early Lead
abstract: After Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player stirred nostalgia among the fans, Spieth, the defending champion, shot a six-under-par 66 in the first round of the Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Nostalgia had its moments on the first morning of the Masters on Thursday.

headline: At Windy Masters, Jordan Spieth Stumbles, and Rory McIlroy Charges In
abstract: McIlroy shot a 71 to move into contention for the only major championship he is missing. He is one shot behind Spieth heading into the third round.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Reduce this year’s Masters to Jordan Spieth versus Rory McIlroy at your peril.

headline: Ernie Els Awakens From His First-Round Nightmare at the Masters
abstract: Els took six putts from 3 feet for an opening nine Thursday, but rebounded in a strong round the next day.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On the practice green before his round on Friday at the Masters, Ernie Els made 25 of 28 putts from inside 9 feet. The last one he struck before making his way to the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club was a 2-footer that dropped in the hole.

headline: Amateur Champion Brushes Off a Bad End at Masters
abstract: After carding his second consecutive even-par 72, Bryson DeChambeau did not rue the shots that got away.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Going into the final hole of his second round at the Masters, Bryson DeChambeau, an amateur, was poised to post the lowest round of the day. On 18, he tried a low stinger to keep the ball from getting caught up in the wind and hit over the top of it. His shot landed in a holly bush, and he had to take an unplayable lie, which led to a triple-bogey seven.

headline: At the Masters and Tantalizingly Close to a Coronation
abstract: Someone on Sunday will experience the feeling of exiting stage left while his playing competitor basks in the spotlight and takes the final bow.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The par-4 closing hole at Augusta National became the Green Quarter-Mile for Brandt Snedeker in 2008. Playing his first Masters as a professional, Snedeker moved into a tie for the lead with his playing competitor, Trevor Immelman, with an eagle on the third hole on the final day.

headline: Jordan Spieth’s Lead Disappears
abstract: On the final two holes, Spieth hit wayward tee shots at Nos. 17 and 18, and compounded his misery with poor wedges. His lead all but disappeared.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The wind played through the Masters on Saturday, blowing sand out of the bunkers and debris onto the greens. It blew the ball of one competitor, Billy Horschel, off the 15th green and into a water hazard, costing him a penalty stroke. The wind was so fierce, it blew Jordan Spieth’s Masters crown askew.

headline: At Augusta and Wimbledon, Similar Auras of Tradition
abstract: Martin Blackman, a United States Tennis Association official, made his inaugural visit to the Masters. The sports may differ, but the clubs are similarly exclusive.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Martin Blackman, head of player development for the United States Tennis Association, made his inaugural visit to the Masters on Saturday.

headline: Europeans’ Masters Title Drought Looms Large in Rory McIlroy’s 77
abstract: European golfers have continued to dominate the United States in the Ryder Cup and have won the other three major tournaments repeatedly. But the Masters has remained elusive.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The photos of past Masters champions are on a wall just inside the clubhouse entrance at Augusta National, and at this stage, you have to do some searching to find the last European champion.

headline: Danny Willett Wins Masters as Jordan Spieth Folds
abstract: Willett, a 28-year-old Englishman, took advantage of missteps by Spieth, who would have been the first player to repeat as champion since Tiger Woods in 2002.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After 63 holes of the 80th Masters, Jordan Spieth was five strokes clear of the field. The last nine holes at Augusta National lay before him like a lush green carpet in a coronation ceremony.

headline: An Intense Competition at the 18th, No Golfers Involved
abstract: Masters patrons scramble — no running! — for places to set up chairs long before the action reaches the final hole.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was 8 a.m. on a Sunday at the 18th green. The leader of the Masters, Jordan Spieth, was not scheduled to tee off for nearly seven hours and was not expected to complete his round for more than 11 hours.

headline: Englishman Rises in the Late-Afternoon Augusta Sun
abstract: Danny Willett’s surprising win was not quite as big a leap as casual golf fans might suspect: He arrived at the Masters ranked 12th in the world.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It had been two weeks of joyful, life-changing whirlwind and with one short putt left to finish off his sparkling 67 in the late Sunday sunshine, Danny Willett removed the white sweater he had worn all day to reveal a green shirt.

headline: Jordan Spieth Absorbs ‘a Tough One’ With Dignity
abstract: As the defending champion at the Masters, Spieth had to brave the trophy and jacket ceremonies and then answer questions, right after his collapse allowed Danny Willett to win.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — “More important than golf,” Jordan Spieth said Sunday night as a preamble to publicly congratulating the new Masters champion, Danny Willett. And with those words, Spieth showed that he would live to laugh about his Masters meltdown.

headline: A Meltdown, on Deadline: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Jordan Spieth wasn’t the only one scrambling at the Masters on Sunday.
first_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Karen Crouse, a sportswriter, describes how she scrambled (on deadline) to cover Jordan Spieth’s unexpected meltdown at the Masters.

headline: For Jordan Spieth, a Four-Week Break Seems to Heal All Wounds
abstract: For his first 18-hole round in front of a paying public since his meltdown at the Masters, Spieth seemed to be in good spirits — and in good form.
first_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Jordan Spieth was standing over his ball on the 10th tee at T.P.C. Sawgrass when Rickie Fowler fished a bottle of water from a cooler and tossed it over Spieth’s head to Justin Thomas on the opposite side of the tee box. Spieth did not flinch.

headline: 20 Years Ago, Tiger Woods Made His Grand Entrance at the Masters
abstract: In 1997, everyone became a footnote to a player whose four victories in his first full season on the PGA Tour included a record win at the Masters.
first_paragraph: Gabriel Hjertstedt made history as a rookie on the PGA Tour, becoming the first Swede to win a tournament. In any other season, he would have stood out among his fellow first-year players. But it was 1997, when everyone — first-year players and veterans alike — became a footnote to Tiger Woods, whose four victories in his first full season as a professional included his record 12-stroke rout at the Masters.

headline: Rory McIlroy on Playing With Trump Again: ‘I’d Think Twice About It’
abstract: McIlroy, who needs a Masters title to complete a career Grand Slam, found himself answering questions about playing golf with President Trump.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It was so much easier for Rory McIlroy eight years ago when he first came to the Masters tournament as nothing more than a winsome 19-year-old, curly-headed wunderkind. Back then, it would have been almost inconceivable that his choice of golfing partners would ignite an international political firestorm.

headline: Jason Day Enters Masters ‘a Little Bit Unprepared’ but With a Clearer Head
abstract: Day, a former No. 1 player who has had to deal with a back injury and his mother’s illness, has few external expectations this year at Augusta.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The beast that is the modern news cycle — the one that demands, What have you done for us in the last hour? — had taken its focus off Jason Day and shifted it to the resplendent rookie Jon Rahm and Dustin Johnson, the world No. 1 and winner of his last three tournaments.

headline: Dustin Johnson Hurts His Back in a Fall, but Still Hopes to Play
abstract: The world’s top-ranked golfer slipped on a set of stairs in the house he is renting for the Masters. He landed “very hard” on his back, his agent said.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Top-ranked Dustin Johnson, who has won his last three tournaments, slipped Wednesday afternoon on a set of stairs in the rental house where he is staying and hurt his back, his agent, David Winkle, confirmed.

headline: It Takes a Small Army to Equal Arnie
abstract: There will never be another Arnold Palmer. But many of his endearing qualities can be found in the men competing at the Masters. Together they form golf’s composite King.
first_paragraph: The first major event after a patriarch’s passing can be rough on his family. As the golf community gathers at Augusta National Golf Club for the Masters this week, Arnold Palmer’s absence from the tournament he dearly loved and won four times will be acutely felt.

headline: Arnold Palmer’s Absence Is Felt at Augusta’s First Tee
abstract: For the first time since 2006, Palmer was not alongside Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player for the ceremonial tee shots at Augusta National Golf Club.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The wind was stinging their faces, but that was not why Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player had tears in their eyes as they prepared for their ceremonial tee shots at the Masters.

headline: Dustin Johnson Withdraws From the Masters With a Back Injury
abstract: Johnson, the world’s top-ranked golfer, sustained a lower back injury in a fall down the stairs of his rental home near the course Wednesday.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The last player to win the Masters while ranked No. 1 in the world was Tiger Woods in 2005. That streak is safe for at least another year after Dustin Johnson withdrew on Thursday because of a lower back injury he sustained in a fall down the stairs of his rental home near the course on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Jordan Spieth Discovers That Disaster Always Lurks at the Masters
abstract: Spieth, done in by a quadruple bogey on the 12th hole in the final round at Augusta last year, parred the hole Thursday, but had a quadruple bogey on the 15th.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Jordan Spieth may have wadded up the quadruple-bogey 7 he made on the 12th hole in the final round of last year’s Masters and pulverized it in his mental trash compactor. But the crowd that blanketed the hill beside Nos. 11 and 12 as Spieth’s group came into view Thursday afternoon had tucked away the memory and carried it through the gates with them.

headline: Charley Hoffman Grabs Four-Stroke First-Round Lead at Windy Augusta
abstract: As gusts of up to 40 miles per hour bedeviled most players, Hoffman shot a remarkable seven-under-par 65, birdieing nine holes, including all four par-3s.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Fred Couples, playing in his 32nd Masters this year, said he had never seen wind so fierce at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Sergio García Shares Masters Lead After Scoring Mishap
abstract: For part of Friday’s second round, García mysteriously gained two strokes, but he is tied with Rickie Fowler, Charley Hoffman and Thomas Pieters at four-under.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For nearly 20 years, Augusta National Golf Club has been Sergio García’s personal torture chamber. As has been his wont, García has persistently lamented his fate on the grounds, as if he were cursed.

headline: Chasing Golf History, Rory McIlroy Struggles With an Elusive Quarry
abstract: Only five men have won a career Grand Slam. To become the sixth, McIlroy must figure out how to ignore the distraction and concentrate on winning the Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — For Rory McIlroy, the Masters title is like a feather. Every time he has tried to grasp it, the energy from his effort has pushed it out of his reach.

headline: Phil Mickelson to Join Jordan Spieth in a Marquee Pairing
abstract: Mickelson and Spieth finished the second round of the Masters tied, so they will tee off together in a pairing that is sure to attract a following.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At 46, Phil Mickelson is twice as old as Jordan Spieth is. But they were equals on the Masters leaderboard Friday, tied at even par after Mickelson carded a 73 and Spieth a 69 on another windy day at Augusta National.

headline: A Note to Tiger Woods: Victory Isn’t the Only Path to Joy
abstract: Woods, a four-time Masters champion who has been battling back issues, could learn from an example set by Arnold Palmer.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Dear Tiger,

headline: Justin Rose and Sergio García Top Leaderboard at Masters
abstract: Rose and García stand at six under par after 54 holes at Augusta National. Rose shot a 67 on Saturday, while Garcia carded a 70.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The 81st Masters tournament is being played in the memory of Arnold Palmer, but it could be dedicated to spine specialists.

headline: Jordan Spieth Returns to Contention by Playing ‘Without Fear’
abstract: Spieth trailed by 10 strokes after the first round but has used an aggressive approach to reduce that deficit to two entering the final round.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Jordan Spieth stood in the woods, his line of sight blocked by a tree and his ball 228 yards from the 13th green.

headline: Masters 2017: Sergio García Finally Wins First Major Title
abstract: Playing in his 74th major tournament, García, 37, outdueled Justin Rose in a playoff to win the green jacket.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Arnold Palmer of Europe was Seve Ballesteros, who was very, very good when he hit his drives straight and even better when they went crooked. In 1980, three months after Sergio García was born, Ballesteros won the first of his two Masters titles.

headline: Same Old Sergio Writes a New Script
abstract: Sergio García had long felt the disdain of fans put off by his attitude. But with a more mellow approach and an underdog’s charm, he won them over at the Masters.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Throughout the first nine holes of Sunday’s final round at the Masters, Sergio García was greeted with thunderous applause from the grandstands. Just 15 years ago, when he was perceived as precocious but persnickety, he was ridiculed by crowds at American major golf championships. But now García, 37, was a fan favorite.

headline: Masters 2017: Europeans Dominated the Leader Board
abstract: Led by Sergio Garcia of Spain, golfers from Europe occupied five of the first eight places.
first_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The 81st Masters began with a look back at the life and legacy of Arnold Palmer, a four-time champion whose death last September hung over Augusta National like the dark rain clouds that burst and wiped out the par-3 contest. It ended with the sun shining luminously on Europe.

headline: Masters Will Play Without Augusta’s Famed Roars
abstract: Augusta National Golf Club announced Wednesday that this year’s tournament will be played without patrons, making it the last of men’s golf majors to bar spectators.
first_paragraph: The Augusta National Golf Club announced Wednesday that the 2020 Masters Tournament, postponed from its traditional April date to Nov. 12 to 15, will be held without patrons or guests in attendance. The decision was a response to the coronavirus pandemic and came after many other fixtures of the men’s professional golf schedule, including last week’s P.G.A. Championship, the first major championship of this unconventional year, previously were conducted without spectators.

headline: Healing Rory McIlroy, and Others, Start Fast in Mexico
abstract: McIlroy, who broke a rib in January and missed four tournaments, carded a 68 and was one stroke off the lead during the first round of a World Golf Championships event.
first_paragraph: NAUCALPAN DE JUÁREZ, Mexico — By the time March rolls around, Rory McIlroy is typically weary of questions about the Masters, the last major title he needs to complete a career Grand Slam. In the lead-up to his past two competitive forays to the Masters at Augusta National, McIlroy has endured an endless loop of questions about his preparedness, his confidence and his putting.

headline: Masters Favorite? Dustin Johnson, With Plenty of Competition
abstract: With his victory in the World Golf Championships event in Mexico, Johnson emerged with the slight edge, but there are many top challengers.
first_paragraph: NAUCALPAN DE JUÁREZ, Mexico — All but one of golf’s leading men assembled for one final casting call to pick a favorite to win the Masters. Given the results of the World Golf Championships event at Club de Golf Chapultepec, Dustin Johnson emerged with the slight edge, but it’s the quality of the ensemble cast that stands out as the PGA Tour heads to Augusta National’s grand stage next month.
